Starting surfit

surfit based on Tcl scripting language, so first of all you must start tclsh. It means that you must have Tcl installed on your computer.

After that you can load libsurfit shared library (or dll) with command:

$ load libsurfit[info sharedlibextension]

Under Windows this command can be simplified:

$ load libsurfit

Under Unix you can type

$ load libsurfit.so

If libsurfit was succesfully loaded into memory, you would see the license text:

surfit version 1.0.0pre, Copyright (C) 2002-2004 M.V.Dmitrievsky & V.N.Kutrunov
surfit comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY; for details type `show_w'.
This is free software, and you are welcome to redistribute it
under certain conditions; type `show_c' for details.

A common error received by first-time users is the following:

$ load libsurfit.so
couldn't load file "libsurfit.so": libsurfit.so: cannot open shared object file:
No such file or directory
$

Unix environment

This error is generated because the dynamic linker can't locate the libsurfit.so library. When shared libraries are loaded, the system normally only checks a few standard locations such as /usr/lib and /usr/local/lib. To fix this problem, there are several things you can do. First, you can set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable to include the directory with libsurfit library. If setting LD_LIBRARY_PATH, be aware that setting this variable can introduce a noticeable performance impact on all other applications that you run. To set it only for Tcl, you might want to do this instead:

$ env LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/beazley/projects/lib tclsh

Finally, you can use a command such as ldconfig to add additional search paths to the default system configuration (this requires root access and you will need to read the man pages).

Windows environment

This error is generated because system can't locate the libsurfit.dll library. To fix this probelm you must set the PATH environment variable to the directory with libsurfit.dll:

(Windows 95/98/Me): The search path in Windows is normally specified in the autoexec.bat file, which is typically located in the root directory (c:\). To add the surfit installation directory to your search path do the following from an MS-DOS Prompt Window:

  • Type the following:
    edit c:\autoexec.bat
  • The contents of your autoexec.bat file will appear in a text editor. Find the line in your autoexec.bat that looks similar to the following:
    PATH C:\DOS;C:\WINDOWS;C:\NETWORK;C:\NAV
  • At the end of this line add the following:
    ;"c:\program files\surfit\bin"
     This assumes that you have installed surfit (libsurfit.dll) in the c:\program files\surfit\bin directory. If you have installed it in another directory, verify that you have entered an appropriate path. The leading semicolon is only necessary if there is not already a semicolon specified at the end of the "PATH" line.
  • Press Alt+F+X. You will be prompted to save the file before exiting. Enter Y.
  • Close any open applications and restart your PC. You may now access libsurfit.dll from any directory without specifying a path. An alternative to steps 2 and 3 above is to add the following line at the end of your autoexec.bat file: SET PATH = "C:\program files\surfit\bin";PATH%
(Windows NT/Windows 2000):
  • Close any open MS-DOS Prompt Windows.
  • Select Settings | Control Panel from the Start Menu.
  • In the Control Panel, double click the System icon. The System (Properties) dialog appears.
  • Select the Environment Tab.
  • Select the PATH variable in the System (Environment) Variables or User (Environment) Variables boxes. If you are unable to locate the PATH variable, enter the following in the Variable box:
    path
    Enter something similar to the following in the Value box:
    "c:\program files\surfit\bin"

Loading data to surfit

Loading from text files

To examine data, already loaded use mem_info command.

loading points

The task_read command reads formatted text files containing interpolation scattered data points coordinates. The text file should organized as a rectangular table of numbers, separated by blanks, with one row per line, and an equal number of elements in each row. For example, outside of surfit, create a text file containing these four lines:

    16.0     3.0     2.0    13.0
     5.0    10.0    11.0     8.0
     9.0     6.0     7.0    12.0
     4.0    15.0    14.0     1.0

Store the file under the name points.txt Then the command

$ task_read points.txt my_points 4 1 2 3
13/01/05 15:02:52 : reading task "my_points" from file points.txt

reads the file and creates a variable, surfit_task, containing 4 points with X,Y and Z coordinates placed in first, second and third columns. If points.txt consists of only 3 columns:

    16.0     3.0     2.0
     5.0    10.0    11.0
     9.0     6.0     7.0
     4.0    15.0    14.0

then the command arguments can be truncated:

$ task_read points.txt my_points
13/01/05 15:02:52 : reading task "my_points" from file points.txt

You can get some info about variables surfit_task and surfit_tasks by following commands:

# Task existance checking:
$ task_check
1
# If surfit_task does not exists, surfit returns 0.
#
# Print surfit_task name
$ task_name
13/01/05 15:02:52 : surfit_task name is "my_points"
#
# Amount of points in task
$ task_size
4
$ Minimum and maximum values:
$ task_minx
4.0
$ task_maxx
16.0
$ task_miny
3.0
$ task_maxy
15.0
$ task_minz
2.0
$ task_maxz
14.0

Here you can browse all commands for task.

The wtask_read command reads formatted text files containing approximation scattered data points coordinates and informational weights. The command

$ wtask_read points.txt my_points

reads the file and creates a variable, surfit_wtask, containing 4 points with X,Y and Z coordinates placed in first, second and third columns. The fourth column is for the informational weights. Here you can browse all commands for wtask.

loading curves

surfit supports several types of curves:
curv 2D piecewise linear curve
area area with constant value for interpolation described with 2D piecewise linear curve
warea area with constant value for approximation described with 2D piecewise linear curve
flt tectonical fault line (describes the line of dissacording of surface parts)
iso isoline for interpolation
wiso isoline for approximation
cntr 3D piecewise linear curve for interpolation
wcntr 3D piecewise linear curve for approximation

The curves reading commands reads formatted text files containing coordinates of curve nodes. The text file should organized as a rectangular table of numbers, separated by blanks, with one row per line, and an equal number of elements in each row. For example, outside of surfit, create a text file curve.txt containing these lines:

57099.085411 	60514.295924
57065.433147 	60505.330833
57003.367936 	60511.976722
56999.6438 	60513.47112
56948.876992 	60541.501355
56917.649718 	60581.114875
56914.83462 	60637.571493
56919.935389 	60652.716872
56959.468869 	60684.079163
56995.964528 	60685.666331
57018.666043 	60682.271289
57060.443913 	60665.765085
57102.780849 	60632.737514
57119.301496 	60610.562283
57133.154687 	60592.618067
57138.674487 	60577.882496
57131.297193 	60533.391477
57116.652575 	60516.980407
57099.085411 	60514.295924

To read curve from file curve.txt into surfit_cntr variable use command: 
$ curv_read curve.txt my_curve
14/01/05 11:00:12 : reading curve "my_curve" from file curve.txt
1

To read isoline for interpolation with 50 value from file curve.txt into surfit_iso variable use command: 
$ iso_read curve.txt my_isoline 50
14/01/05 11:16:10 : reading iso "my_isoline" from file curve.txt
1

Here you can browse all commands for working with curves.

loading functions

surfit supports several types of functions (surfaces):
func function for interpolation
wfunc function for approximation
trend trend function to describe general function behaviour
defarea domain of the function

Functions (surfaces) can be loaded from Surfer GRD-ASCII and surfit extension of ROFF files. To load surface from Surfer GRD-ASCII file into surfit_func variable use command:

$ func_load_grd surface.grd my_surface
14/01/05 16:32:50 : loading surface from Surfer GRD-ASCII format file surface.grd
1

To load surface from surfit extension of ROFF file into surfit_func variable use command:

$ func_load surface.dat my_surface
14/01/05 16:33:20 : loading func "my_surface" from file surface.dat
1

You can load other types of surfaces from Surfer GRD-ASCII:

$ wfunc_load_grd surface.grd my_surface 10
14/01/05 16:34:13 : loading surface from Surfer GRD-ASCII format file surface.grd
1
$ trend_load_grd surface.grd 1 2
14/01/05 16:36:41 : loading surface from Surfer GRD-ASCII format file surface.grd
1

Creating grid

surfit uses equdistants grid for gridding procedures. This grid can be described with only 6 parameters:

  • X-coordinate of the first node of the grid
  • X-coordinate of the last node of the grid
  • cell size in X-direction
  • Y-coordinate of the first node of the grid
  • Y-coordinate of the last node of the grid
  • cell size in Y-direction
Using surfit you can create grid with grid_get command. For example, command

$ grid_get 0 100 10 0 200 20 my_grid
15/01/05 22:38:32 : grid: (0.00 <-> 100.00) / 10.00; (0.00 <-> 200.00) / 20.00.

In most cases you can use grid_auto with only 2 parameters to specify cell sizes:

$ grid_auto 10 20

surfit automatically produces surfit_grid with cells of specified size. This grid will cover all of data, loaded into memory.

Gridding

Gridding methods produce a regularly spaced, rectangular array of Z values from regularly and irregularly spaced XYZ data. The term "irregularly spaced" means that the points follow no particular pattern over the extent of the map, so there are many "holes" where data are missing. Gridding fills in these holes by extrapolating or interpolating Z values at those locations where no data exists.

For each data type, loading into surfit memory you can specify priority level using priority variable.

Gridding procedure consists of 3 steps:

  • load data into memory
  • create grid
  • execute solve procedure
Here is some examples:

  • Interpolation of scattered data points
  • Interpolation of scattered data points with faults
  • Interpolation of scattered data points with trend and fault
  • Approximation of scattered data points
  • Interpolation of isolines
  • Approximation of isolines
  • Interpolation of contours
  • Approximation of contours
  • Interpolation of areas
  • Approximation of areas
  • Interpolation of ordered data poinst
  • Approximation of ordered data points

Saving results

After gridding procedure results saves to surfit_func variable. You can export it to Surfer GRD-ASCII format with command func_save_grd or to and surfit extension of ROFF files with command func_save. Also to save your results into surfit extension of ROFF files with all other data in memory use command file_save.

Visualising results

The simplest way to visualise your results is to use funner tool: just press "Open File..." button and select file to visualise. funner accepts both Surfer GRD-ASCII and ROFF files.

Press "V I E W" button to visualise surfit memory and other buttons to select data to view.

Also you can select file from command line:

$ funner map_wfunc.dat

Another usable tool for advanced users is Bula.

Working with ROFF files

surfit extends ROFF file format for saving and loading various kind of data objects. One ROFF file can contain several objects. Then you saving some data to ROFF file surfit can add this data to the end of file or rewrite file. This behaviour rules with variable datafile_mode. For each data-object exists command like 

"ObjectType_save"
which saves object to ROFF file.

Special command file_save saves all data from surfit memory to ROFF file. Command file_load loads all data from ROFF file to surfit memory. To examine data, already loaded use mem_info command.

surfit-1.0.0pre
